When i first wrote that, i was probably making an excuse for the song not being good enough. the original version of that was "i don't have enough time to write the song i want to sing, so please don't judge me one little bit". then, 2 years later, i re-wrote it with possibly slightly more experienced songwriting abilities

I wanna write a song
Oh, baby is that so wrong?

---I believe this refers to how we wanted to do something, but people would often try to stop us, even if the thing we're doing isn't bad

i just wanted to write songs, and i couldn't really figure out why it was more difficult than i expected, considering the fact that i already had multiple decades of musical experience prior to that point, in addition to having written dozens of songs already, many years before that

I went down to the mall
Then they closed down the mall
Guess they don't want me going to the mall
'Cause I'm just too small

---This references on how sometimes people think we're to young to some stuff

the 'too small' line is the worst line in the song. it is literally just a rhyme. horrible. i am against doing this. it breaks one of my best rules of songwriting, which is don't do that. The triple mall line(s), however, i stand behind. And it's basically my way of plowing fearlessly into the second verse. Think of it this way ........ i had just selected this song the day before, to be the next one that's recorded, and i was having major remorse about it (despite having been very diligent in the song selection). I really was feeling down about the whole thing, and i had already changed my mind about it and chose to do a much sadder and slower song instead. But then i was doubting that one just as much, so, i was actually at the barber and i was waiting for a hair cut, and i was trying to comprehend what went wrong in the song choice. So i came back to thinking about this 'la de da' song. At the time, the song was only written up until the end of the first chorus. so i guess i just briefly posed the question, 'what if i COULD do this one.... and what would the second verse most likely be, if i did it' and just as i was getting into the barber chair, the first 3 mall lines assaulted me right in the face. And i was immediately convinced that that seals the deal for the song choice, but that particular burst of writing went no further. and i was left to toil in the mud when i got home to try to complete the phrase. i made a bad decision, and i suppose i tried to mask it with background vocal arrangements

I just went online
To explain the things I feel
To express the things I mean
 And it f elt so real

---This refers to how we spent more time online than offline, and how our internet connection becomes more important

i think, if you are talking about the last line, i think it is playing on the fact that the internet is real, while also using a phrase like "it felt so real" which is a phrase commonly associated with things that *might* not be real. so i was attempting to provide a little bit of intrigue there. Also one thing you forgot to mention was that i switched the words in the more common phrases 'explain the things i mean' and 'express the things i feel'. i switched the verbs, to see if it means something slightly different. turns out it does

Now I'm doing alright
And I'm downright feeling okay
It's the end of the world
And I just can't wait

--- Deppression?
no, this is just meant to provide an alternate flavor of the line in the corresponding position in the verse before this. which you conveniently did not mention yet

I know that you can relate

---Yes
it seems to be fairly common for people to make casual conversation about the world being all wrong

Then I built some trains
And I'm travelling somewhere new
It's a wonderful world, but
Still no you
It's a wonderful world for two

---This part describes our journey on finding happiness, we realize the world is beautiful, but we still can't find happiness (referenced by "still no you", you references happiness)

you mentioned this out of order, but this comes after the "just too small" line. Perhaps the 'built some trains', 'traveling somewhere new' was my way getaway scheme, to escape from the blandness of the previous line. Or just assuming the mall was not a viable option. it is a natural progression to take a train somewhere else.... but with 10,000 bonus points for building your own train.
When the subject of 'traveling somewhere new' comes up, it becomes impossible not to mention how wonderful the world is. when you think of all the possible places you could go. But then, when realizing that, the NEXT thing to immediately realize is it would be nice to have some companionship as well. OR, there is also a double meaning to 'still no you' line, it could also mean the world IS "no you". like, it's still doesn't compare to you. That's just in case maybe you took a look around at the world and still think it's not as good as it could be. so in that case you would be singing TO something which you think could be even better than the world. So in that moment, the line seems to mean those 2 things. But when the next line hits ('wonderful world for 2') i think it becomes more clear that it actually meant the first thing

And now for the main part, the la de da part

 And it goes La de da de da de da de day oh
La de da de where did all the good times go? (
La de da de la da dee d um dom L a da de day
When will you come back home?

the lines immediately before this were basically begging to write a song. we have already essentially looked in the mirror and stated the wish 3 times, pretty much there is nowhere else to go but to actually do it. "La de da" etc. would be a meta characterization of a song being written
happiness without reason.

---The tune (or the sound, music, I don't know what you actually call them) is a joyful expression. The la de da part sounds happy. Combine this with the meaningless of the lyrics, this means happiness without reason.
i think the problem is you are blatantly ignoring all the meaning

---Genuine happiness is actually rare this days. Yes, we often feel happy, like when we just won a game match, or we get a promotion at work, but that happiness is only temporary. If the condition changes (like we lose the next game, or someone accidentally hit our car when we're going home from work) we will no longer be happy
---Gen uine happiness, on the other hand, doesn't have a reason. it's being happy simply because we existed. It's a feeling of being grateful because we're still here, regardless on the situation. This is what we all wanted. The words "When will you come back home" expresses our search for this happiness, as we continue to wait for happiness to come to us.

1. How did you evolve into 3D animating?

first, i wrote a video about the history of the entire world. So i really needed to show the locations on a 3 dimensional globe. So then once i had cracked the ice on that skill set, i started to use tiny bits of 3D in every video after that. but then eventually i started to realize that i wasn't really giving myself enough time to give it a chance. Then one day when starting the music video i decided to start the whole thing in the 3D environment. well it blew my mind, to such a severe extent that it made me decide to take a giant and decisive leap into that realm

What inspired "the road"? It's surreal but it still feels like it's grounded in something.

during 2009 and 2010 especially, i was doing this thing where i would write songs on paper only, with no instrument. Just start at the beginning and see where it goes. i wrote a lot of songs that way. i guess you could call it 'chain writing', or 'train writing', because the whole thing is written in order. And it's all done on the chart, on paper. Then around 2011 i got envious of more 'normal' songs, so i finally learned how to be organized enough to work on songs at an instrument, find a chorus first maybe, learn how to write what's before the chorus, you know, normal stuff. So i did a lot of that during 2011. Near the beginning of 2012, however, there was a day where i fondly remembered the joy of 'chain writing' so i did some of those. and 'the road' is one of them. So it is likely that the contents of the song somehow reflects the context of that situation

I teach singer/songwriters and I get a lot of the beginner songwriters coming to me and saying stuff like "I just don't know how to get the pieces of the song together. I don't know how it's supposed to sound. Why doesn't my song have a longer chorus? My phrases are too short! Blah blah blah" and they make these statements about the entirety of their work as if their songs need to be XYZ kind of way. It's like they want me to tell them that there's a RIGHT and a WRONG way to make a song good. And when I tell them that it sounds like they're asking for an acceptable formula, their eyes kind of glaze over. They say "I don't want my songs to be formulaic! I just want to know the right way to write a song" but in my mind those are the same thing. What I've told them is this - make up your own formula for an individual song. However you want the patterns to be and then fit your segments into the formula YOU create. I'm hoping at a minimum this will make t hem focu s more on their own instincts and less on right and wrong. But I can't tell. What do you think I should tell them?
reverse psychology can go a long way. Tell them to try to write it wrong. it's amazing how quickly it becomes very right

I struggle between choosing to spend my time coming up with new ideas or finish existing ones that I started. I want to have a goal of 1 new musical idea per *reasonable amount of time*, but I don't know how to prioritize between investing time into new things when I have ideas outstanding that need attention. Do you have any suggestions/have you experienced this? thanks

basically what i did, when i was first in your situation, is to just keep coming up with new ideas. let them pile up. This is probably because i may have had a fear of not having enough ideas. Then it rapidly became a problem. Another thing i began doing is writing songs entirely on paper, and i would demand to finish the whole thing in 1 session. That's one way of dealing with it. so i wrote more and more and more. Sometimes they wouldn't get finished, sometimes they would. Usually if it was shorter, it would get finished. but they all got put into the list regardless. more years went by with more writing like this. It was more rare that i would ever record any of them. Eventually when the problem became even more serious, i finally found a way to work on the existing ideas. This is a whole separate task from generating new ideas, and i still consider them separate. For a couple years i ONLY did 'middle writing', which is where i work on existing ideas. Then a few months later, as i was getting ready to start recording some of them, i did a few weeks of finishing, just finishing writing for songs. I could talk for years about the different systems i've used for SELECTING which ones to work on. And this is not even to discuss selections for the recording process, which you didn't ask about. Eventually as enough years go by, you start to feel your life running out, so you probably take drastic measures. Nowadays, for me this is how it works: new ideas can come any time, that's always true. Sometimes they even come in dreams. So i catch them whenever they arrive, and i don't really do a writing session at that time because it's usually not the right time. but you just try to catch as much as you can. That's totally separate from any writing process or work process. Separately from that, it is a linear process of working toward the item i am releasing next, and i work on that 1 item until it's done. For songs, first what i do, at the beginning of a project, i do a round of new song idea generation, but this is NOT necessarily promising that any of these will be the one that's used. This is just to ensure that i am giving myself a chance to generate new ideas, which might have a chance of getting picked. So i generate some new ideas, maybe 10 or 15. Sometimes i use various different methods, just to make sure i've given myself a chance to try various things. Then, when that's done, i do song 'selection', which is where i'm going to choose which one is going to be recorded, for the next release. This selection is made from the ENTIRE list, which includes the new ones but also includes all the other ones, which are all at various levels of completion (writing). Once a selection is made, then it's quite simple. I finish the writing all the way, first, then record it, all the way. then make the video, all the way. I should clarify that this procedure didn't become solidified until after many many many years of ambiguity which may be similar to what you are going through now

I'm a high school music teacher, and I get the sense that you avoid talking about your school years because you've realized what pretty much every musician needs to realize at one point or another if they are going to improve their musicianship.That the only person who can improve your musicianship is you.You have to the do the work, the ear training, the practicing, the time song writing and creating.

So here's my question(s).How did you develop your work ethic for creating music?

it's similar to the way a person might develop a habit of using crack-cocaine, except instead of 1 drug it's more like 1000, because there is at least 1000 different ways to become totally and deeply hooked into music
Did people in your life have an influence on you developing this skill?

i was able to hear a lot of music on records (and through the television of course, paired with visuals in such a way that i may not even realize until decades later just how crucial the audio-visual relationship is) and i will confess i also had access to a piano/keyboard instrument, and a drum set. There were also guitars around, but i've always been a bit overwhelmed/intimitated by guitars. having an extremely early start, it was pretty natural to find myself in many many personal and professional music relationships with peers (well at first it was usually people much older than me because i was so young to start)
What do you think music teachers could be doing better to try and foster this skill in other people?

what i think is the best approach, for me personally, is to write and record the best songs i can. if i can get them good enough, then maybe that will help someone else hear just a glimpse of what may be possible, just the way i might have heard someone else before, even if it's just for 7 seconds coming out of a car window going around the corner

or an A section), how do you go about making a transition into a new section (voice leading? music theory tool? Wild guessing? Wikipedia?)? THANK YOU!

do a fresh run-through from the beginning, at the exact tempo. the more refreshed you are, the better this will work. It works the best if you haven't heard the song in a day. do a fresh run-through, and then just as you start to approach the end of what you have, that is when lightning will strike, if it does. listen very closely in that moment, and try to gather as many details as you can about what you think you are hearing next. Another trick which often produces results is to imagine the song is taking place in a scene. imagine a visual story for the song to take place in. Also another thing i almost forgot to mention, in case you are not doing already, try to use words/language for this
